content: The Act may be cited as the "Truth in Lending Act Amendments of 1995" and includes provisions regarding certain charges. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments of 1995 address third party fees and borrower-paid mortgage broker fees, specifying that certain charges should not be included in the finance charge. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments of 1995 specify that borrower-paid mortgage broker fees should be regulated by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System within 6 months of the Act's enactment. Additionally, any taxes on security instruments or evidences of indebtedness must be paid before recording the instrument. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments of 1995 require borrower-paid mortgage broker fees to be regulated by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System within 6 months. Taxes on security instruments or evidences of indebtedness must be paid before recording the instrument. Amendments include fees for loan document preparation and fees related to pest infestations, inspections, and hazards. The Board of Governors must submit a report to Congress with recommendations on regulatory or statutory changes within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Board of Governors must submit a report to Congress with recommendations on regulatory or statutory changes necessary to ensure that finance charges accurately reflect the cost of credit and address abusive refinancing practices. The report should consider including all charges payable by the consumer and imposed by the creditor as part of finance charges. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System will consult with affected industries and consumer groups to make regulatory changes regarding finance charges, as required by the Truth in Lending Act. They must publish any regulation in the Federal Register within one year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 3. TOLERANCES; BASIS OF DISCLOSURES. In connection with credit transactions secured by real property or a dwelling, the finance charge disclosure must not vary by more than $100 or exceed the required amount under the Truth in Lending Act. The finance charge disclosure must not vary by more than a certain percentage of the total credit amount for specific types of transactions, as outlined in the Truth in Lending Act. The Truth in Lending Act specifies that for consumer credit transactions with per diem interest, the disclosure accuracy is based on information known to the creditor at the time of preparing the transaction documents. SEC. 4. LIMITATION ON LIABILITY. Amends the Truth in Lending Act to add a new section regarding certain limitations on liability. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments of 1995 limit the liability of creditors or assignees for certain consumer credit transactions made before the enactment date. This includes specific exemptions related to disclosure of taxes, fees, and mortgage broker fees, as well as the form of written notice to inform consumers of their rights under the Act. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments of 1995 limit creditor liability for consumer credit transactions. Exceptions include accurate finance charge disclosures within $200 of actual charge or greater than required amount. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments of 1995 limit creditor liability for consumer credit transactions, with exceptions for certain cases filed before specific dates or with timely notice of rescission sent before June 1, 1995. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments of 1995 limit creditor liability for consumer credit transactions. Section 125 of the Act is amended to include a limitation on rescission rights based on the form of written notice provided by the creditor. Additionally, there are provisions for calculating damages. SEC. 6. CALCULATION OF DAMAGES. Amends the Truth in Lending Act to specify damages in individual actions related to credit transactions secured by real property or a dwelling. SEC. 7. ASSIGNEE LIABILITY. Section 131 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to add a new subsection regarding the liability of assignees for violations apparent on the face of transaction documents in consumer credit transactions secured by real property. Civil actions against a creditor for violations can be maintained against an assignee only if the violation is evident on the disclosure statement and the assignment was voluntary. The amendment to the Truth in Lending Act adds a subsection regarding assignee liability for violations apparent on transaction documents in real property consumer credit transactions. Assignees can be held liable only if violations are evident on the disclosure statement and the assignment was voluntary. The servicer of a consumer obligation from a credit transaction is not considered an assignee unless they are or were the owner of the obligation. The servicer cannot be treated as the owner based on an assignment for administrative convenience. Upon request, the servicer must provide the obligor with information about the owner of the obligation. The term 'servicer' in consumer credit transactions is defined as in the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act of 1974. This subsection applies to all credit transactions after the Truth in Lending Act Amendments of 1995. SEC. 8. RESCISSION RIGHTS IN FORECLOSURE. Section 125 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include new subsection (i) regarding Rescission Rights in Foreclosure. This allows the obligor to rescind a transaction if a mortgage broker fee was not included in the finance charge during a foreclosure process on their primary dwelling. The Truth in Lending Act allows consumers to rescind a transaction if the finance charge disclosures are inaccurate during a foreclosure process on their primary dwelling. The Truth in Lending Act allows consumers to rescind a transaction if the finance charge disclosed does not vary by more than $35 from the actual finance charge or exceeds the required amount. This right of recoupment under State law is not affected by this subsection. It applies to all consumer credit transactions after the Truth in Lending Act Amendments of 1995.
